user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 21.17.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
Yes — try_match_header is called with a fixed length (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_("Content-Transfer-Encoding: ")) but there is no check that the buffer contains that many bytes. If the stored header line is shorter than that prefix (or pp->buffer_size is less than the static prefix length, e.g. prefix length = 27) the helper will attempt to read MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ bytes from buf and may access beyond the bounds of pp's buffer. For example, if pp->buffer_size < MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_("Content-Transfer-Encoding: ") (or newline < that length) the comparison inside try_match_header can read past the allocated buffer and thus violate Rule 21.17.
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified process_multipart_headers code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/1423.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_multipart_headers:
```c
static int
process_multipart_headers (struct MHD_PostProcessor *pp,
                           size_t *ioffptr,
                           enum PP_State next_state)
{
  char *buf = (char *) &pp[1];
  size_t newline;

  newline = 0;
  while ( (newline < pp->buffer_pos) &&
          (buf[newline] != '\r') &&
          (buf[newline] != '\n') )
    newline++;
  if (newline == pp->buffer_size)
  {
    pp->state = PP_Error;
    return MHD_NO;              /* out of memory */
  }
  if (newline == pp->buffer_pos)
    return MHD_NO;              /* will need more data */
  if (0 == newline)
  {
    /* empty line - end of headers */
    pp->skip_rn = RN_Full;
    pp->state = next_state;
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  /* got an actual header */
  if (buf[newline] == '\r')
    pp->skip_rn = RN_OptN;
  buf[newline] = '\0';
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ ("Content-disposition: ",
                                 buf,
                                 MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ("Content-disposition: ")))
  {
    try_get_value (&buf[MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ("Content-disposition: ")],
                   "name",
                   &pp->content_name);
    try_get_value (&buf[MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ("Content-disposition: ")],
                   "filename",
                   &pp->content_filename);
  }
  else
  {
    try_match_header ("Content-type: ",
                      MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ("Content-type: "),
                      buf,
                      &pp->content_type);
    try_match_header ("Content-Transfer-Encoding: ",
                      MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ("Content-Transfer-Encoding: "),
                      buf,
                      &pp->content_transfer_encoding);
  }
  (*ioffptr) += newline + 1;
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified process_multipart_headers code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original process_multipart_headers with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as process_multipart_headers.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call process_multipart_headers to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of process_multipart_headers as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, process_multipart_headers will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of process_multipart_headers as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
